ALEX BEAM
discusses
A Great Idea at the Time:
The Rise, Fall, and Curious Afterlife
of
The Great Books

From the Harvard Book Store webpage: Harvard Book Store is pleased to welcome novelist and award-winning Boston Globe columnist ALEX BEAM for a discussion of his newest book, A Great Idea at the Time: The Rise, Fall, and Curious Afterlife of the Great Books.

"What if all you needed to know could be gleaned from a select number of books? That was the idea behind the Great Books of the Western World project launched in 1952 by the University of Chicago and the Encyclopedia Britannica. No mind that you'd attempted Aeschylus in a freshman seminar and found it musty. All it needed was a snazzy binding and poof -- education for the masses. Or at least something to fill up those capacious bookshelves in the den. Alex Beam’s A Great Idea at the Time looks at the postwar fascination with the Great Books, evoking a moment when pop culture and education merged.” -The Los Angeles Times

“A witty look at the publishing program that aimed to bring high culture to the masses…or at least the aspiring middle class.” -Kirkus Reviews (starred)

Alex Beam is an award-winning columnist for the Boston Globe. His writing has also appeared in the Atlantic, Slate, the New York Times and many other magazines. The author of Gracefully Insane: Life and Death Inside America’s Premier Mental Hospital, and of two novels, he lives in Boston.>*

This is a Harvard Book Store event.
